noun.description: The effect whereby the position or direction of an object appears to differ when viewed from different positions, e.g. through the viewfinder and the lens of a camera.
examples: what you see in the viewfinder won't be quite what you get in the photograph because of parallax error

origin: Late 16th century (also in the general sense fact of seeing wrongly): from French parallaxe, from Greek parallaxis a change, from parallassein to alternate, based on allassein to exchange (from allos other).
